title: 111_s3810
content: The Act is titled the "Gulf Security and Iran Sanctions Enforcement Act" and includes a restriction on participation in offshore oil and gas leasing. The "Gulf Security and Iran Sanctions Enforcement Act" mandates that leases for drilling on the Outer Continental Shelf include a certification requirement to ensure compliance with Iran sanctions. Failure to certify annually may result in lease cancellation. The "Gulf Security and Iran Sanctions Enforcement Act" requires leases for drilling on the Outer Continental Shelf to include a provision mandating disclosure of any involvement in energy-related ventures outside Iran with blocked individuals or entities. The "Gulf Security and Iran Sanctions Enforcement Act" mandates lease holders to disclose any ties to individuals or entities involved in weapons of mass destruction proliferation or listed on specific regulations. The Secretary can cancel the lease if false information is provided, with a waiver option available on a case-by-case basis. The Secretary of the Interior must report to congressional committees on waivers granted and lease cancellations under the "Gulf Security and Iran Sanctions Enforcement Act." Appropriate committees include those related to natural resources, foreign affairs, energy, and foreign relations. The term "person" is defined in section 14(14) of the Iran Sanctions Act of 1996 (50 U.S.C. 1701 note). The Act will end 30 days after the President certifies to Congress that Iran has stopped supporting terrorism, pursuing weapons of mass destruction, and no longer poses a threat to US national security or allies.
